webTitle: Admiral drifts lower after results hit by falling insurance premiums

fields.standfirst: Motor specialist says turnover dropped 7% in first quarter despite 6% rise in customers
fields.body:
Car insurer Admiral was counting the cost of falling UK premiums as it disappointed the market with its latest update.

It said turnover dropped 7% in the first three months of the year despite 6% growth in customer numbers and a 2% rise in the vehicles it insured. Premiums fell 11% year on year, although that looks like a better performance than the overall market, judging by the 19% drop according to a recent survey by Towers Watson and Admiral's confused.com website.

Overseas, the company reported a 13% rise in turnover. Chief executive Henry Engelhardt said:

Little has changed since the full year results, and our expectations for 2014 remain positive and unchanged.

Even so, its shares have fallen 15p to £14.33.m Andy Hughes at Exane BNP Paribas put a £10.64 price target on the company, saying:

We believe the market is expecting management to be able to maintain high cyclical earnings of over 100p a share and placing those earnings on a multiple of over 14 times. During 2014, this expectation is likely to change as the impact of price competition becomes clearer.

Oriel Securities was also negative:

This statement shows little to make us more positive on Admiral Group. UK turnover and premiums were down, which when taken together with increased policyholders means a lower average premium per vehicle. This could be positive if this was a result of Admiral drastically reducing its risk tolerance (older drivers, more years no claims bonus, etc) but there is no indication of this. The statement points to focusing on retention which may indicate that it is trying to match competing quotes in order to retain customers. If this is the case, we should expect worse combined ratios, or lower margins than previously.
We retain our sell recommendation and price target of 900p.

However Numis issued a buy note on the business, saying:

From the brief statement Admiral looks to be on track to meet market forecasts - the company says that its expectations for 2014 remain positive and unchanged. The UK pricing environment remains a significant drag, but we think Admiral's comments imply a less negative environment than recently suggested by the confused.com and AA rate surveys. We continue to think that near-term earnings and dividends remain underpinned by positive reserve developments, with significant medium-to-long term upside potential from UK and International growth.

webTitle: Goldilocks economy returns – Bank governor's message in quarterly update

fields.standfirst: UK economy neither too hot nor too cold, which is why interest rates staying put for time being, soothes BoE chief Mark Carney
fields.body:
Goldilocks is back. That was the message from Mark Carney as the governor of the Bank of England delivered his quarterly update on the state of the economy.

Growth will average 3% a year for the next three, the amount of slack left after the deep recession of 2008-09 will be used up only gradually, inflation will hover around the government's 2% target, unemployment will continue to fall gently and productivity will eventually return to its pre-recession levels.

The economy is neither too hot nor too cold, which is why official interest rates are staying put for the time being. In the financial markets, there has been much speculation lately about the timing of the first increase in borrowing costs.

Carney was keen to put this speculation to bed. Nothing had really changed since the Bank's last inflation report in February, although the passage of time means that the economy has edged closer to the point at which rates will be lifted from the emergency level of 0.5%.

At the margin, there have been developments since February. Three months ago the Bank's estimate of the amount of spare capacity was 1-1.5% of national output: it now thinks it is closer to 1% than 1.5%. The unemployment rate by early 2017 is now predicted to be 5.9% rather than 6.3%.

But the Bank is content with the way things are progressing. There was no hint from Carney that rates are going up this year, with the first move likely to be in the first half of 2015. Threadneedle Street's aim has been to use forward guidance to reassure households and businesses that they can borrow without the risk of an imminent rise in borrowing costs. This strategy remains in force.

The question, though, is whether Britain will continue to be a Goldilocks economy. Consider the evidence. The economy grew by more than 3% in the year to the first quarter of 2014 with no sign of the pace of expansion abating.

House prices are rising at an annual rate of around 10%, depending on which measure of the property market is used. Unemployment has come down much more rapidly than the Bank was expecting when it announced forward guidance in August. Interest rates remain at 0.5%, providing a considerable stimulus to the economy for a sixth successive year.

Carney did not mention Goldilocks in his press conference. Instead, he used a World Cup metaphor, describing the economy as having come through the qualifying rounds but with the bigger test lying ahead. To which he might have added: pre-tournament confidence is quickly dashed as structural weakness become apparent, leading to the team returning early, bitter postmortems on what went wrong, and calls for the manager's head.

webTitle: Cameron and Miliband clash at PMQs over Pfizer's AstraZeneca bid

fields.standfirst: Labour leader accused of playing politics but Milband says PM's ideology means he cannot stand up for national interest
fields.body:
David Cameron has accused Ed Miliband of placing the interests of the Labour party ahead of those of the nation after he declined to meet the head of Pfizer, which is launching a £63bn takeover of AstraZeneca.

The prime minister rejected suggestions that he has acted as a PR adviser for Pfizer, saying that Labour was guilty of an "abject surrender" over the Kraft takeover of Cadbury when it was in government.

Cameron turned on Miliband after the BBC reported that he had last month declined a meeting with Ian Read, the Scottish-born chief executive of Pfizer, on the grounds that he was busy campaigning in the local and European parliamentary elections. Miliband later changed his mind.

The prime minister told MPs that he was committed to ensuring that British jobs and AstraZeneca's research and development base would be protected in any takeover.

But he added: "The only difference between us is how do you get assurances [from Pfizer].  … I say get stuck in, negotiate hard, fight for Britain. He says stand up, play politics and put that before the national interest."

Cameron dismissed Miliband's call for a change to extend the grounds that could trigger a public interest test on a takeover and said: "The country is getting stronger and he is getting weaker."

Miliband said of Cameron: "He is falling back on the old idea that the market always knows best and doesn't need rules. From Royal Mail to AstraZeneca this is a prime minister whose ideology means he cannot stand up for the national interest."

webTitle: Boohoo boosted by Investec buy note

fields.standfirst: Broker says online fashion retailer could be worth 85p compared to 50p flotation price
fields.body:
Boohoo.com, the online fashion retailer, is barely higher than its March flotation price, but analysts at Investec believe investors should not be unduly upset.

The company's shares are currently up 1p at 51.25p, compared to the 50p level at which shares were sold to investors. But they could be worth 85p, according to Investec's Kate Calvert. She said:

We view boohoo as a brand and design led online player with an under-rated competitive advantage in sourcing and supply chain, operating in a market with attractive structural growth globally.
The recent IPO has given boohoo the clout to accelerate a multi-stage infrastructure investment plan designed to support its longer-term £1bn sales target versus 2014 estimated sales of £109m. It also has the marketing muscle to build scale internationally, which already accounts for 36% of sales. We initiate at buy with a target price of 85p.

webTitle: UK unemployment figures: what the economists say

fields.standfirst: 'There still appears to be plenty of slack in the labour market which is keeping a lid on pay growth ...'
fields.body:
Samuel Tombs, UK economist at Capital Economics

“While the economic recovery is creating jobs at a rapid pace, there still appears to be plenty of slack in the labour market which is keeping a lid on pay growth.

“For a start, the jobless rate is still at a historically high level. Indeed, note that the unemployment rate fell to as low as 5% in the early 2000s and even then the labour market was not a source of much inflationary pressure.

”What’s more, the share of part-time workers who would like to work longer hours and temporary employees that would like a permanent job both remain very high.

"In addition, more than two thirds of the increase in overall employment has reflected a rise in the number of self-employed and there is evidence to suggest that many of these workers are underemployed at present.”

Chris Williamson, chief economist at Markit

“The extent of the labour market improvement over the past year has been the big surprise for policymakers. A steeper than anticipated drop in unemployment forced the Bank of England into amending its original forward guidance, which focused on the unemployment rate dropping below 7% before rate hikes would be considered, and causing it to bring forward its original estimates of when interest rates will start rising.

“The Bank’s focus is likely to rest on pay growth: until pay starts to rise at a rate well in excess of inflation, policymakers will be relaxed about keeping policy low for long.”

John Philpott, director of The Jobs Economist

“The number of people in work in the UK continues to rise at a remarkable rate, helping to cut unemployment to 6.8%. But a jobs boom driven by the fast swelling ranks of the self-employed – who account for two-thirds of the latest increase in employment - is not being matched by a corresponding boost to employee pay, the recent improvement in which appears for the time being to have run out of steam.

“The good news from the latest jobs and pay figures is that they suggest UK unemployment can probably fall much further and much faster without triggering wage inflation. The bad news is that there is still a very long way to go before workers notice any significant improvement in their real standard of living.”

David Kern, chief economist at the British Chambers of Commerce

“To consolidate the upturn, we need to see rises in productivity, which would make it possible for higher pay rises to be affordable. In addition, we need to see tougher action on youth and long term unemployment. While the improvement does not justify immediate action on interest rates, we expect the MPC to provide greater clarity in this area.”

Alan Clarke, head of fixed income strategy at Scotia Bank

“Wage inflation was much lower than expected. A drop from 1.4% to 1.3% in the headline measure might not sound like much but in an environment where the upstream indicators were screaming out upside risks for wages, this is a real disappointment.

“Including bonuses the wage measure is a bit polluted by the bonus timing a year ago. That measure posted a decline of around 1.5% month on month – which held the headline annual rate stable at 1.7%. That was a similar drop to this time a year ago, so there is a good case for a bounce back next month. But if we don’t get a bounce back, then this is a strong justification for the MPC to delay the first hike.”

Rob Harbron, UK economist at the CEBR

“The labour market continues to provide good news for the UK and will likely cheer the Chancellor ahead of next year’s election. However, as the unemployment rate and hence spare capacity continue to fall, pressure will grow on the Bank of England to start raising rates. We will find out the Monetary Policy Committee’s current view on spare capacity later today, when the Bank’s latest Inflation Report is released. However, expect a base rate rise before May 2015.”

webTitle: FTSE slips from 14 year high but Compass climbs after plan to return £1bn to investors

fields.standfirst: Investors pause for breath after recent rises as several companies go ex-dividend
fields.body:
Leading shares have edged back from their 14 year highs, not helped by a number of major companies going ex-dividend.

But heading higher is Compass, up 41.5p or 4% to £10.22 after the catering group said it would hand back £1bn to shareholders via a special dividend. The news came as Compass said half year profits had climbed 5.7% to a better than expected £608m, helped by a strong performance in North America. The company signed new deals with universities, hospitals and businesses including DreamWorks and Nomura. Analyst James Hollins at Investec said:

Compass is ably demonstrating the consistent growth and cash returns which drive our deep admiration for the business; we retain it as a key sector pick. We continue to forecast double-digit earnings per share compound annual growth rate from 2015-2017, while shareholders are treated to a £1bn (5.7% yield) special dividend announced today. Forex headwinds remain (strong sterling), although the projected around 6% free cash flow yield in 2015/2016 implies potential for further payouts. Buy.

Overall the FTSE 100 has edged 13.04 points lower to 6860.04 as investors paused for breath after a mixed performance from Asian markets and Wall Street coming off its best levels.

ITV is the biggest faller in the leading index, down 9.4p at 181.6p after the broadcaster said its share of viewing so far this year had been lower than expected, but it hoped the World Cup in June would give a boost to its business.

Among the companies going ex-dividend were J Sainsbury, down 14.7p at 324.3p, Kingfisher, 9.5p lower at 408p and GlaxoSmithKline, off 21.5p at 1615.5p. The pharmaceuticals group has also seen a former Chinese executive accused of bribery.

3i is leading the mid-cap gainers, up 15.7p at 394p after the investment group said full year net asset value per share had climbed 12% to 348p and it had completed £669m of sales during the year.

webTitle: Pfizer hits back at AstraZeneca's drug death delay claims

fields.standfirst: Boss Ian Read 'sees no risk of delays for any important products for Pfizer or AstraZeneca' if takeover goes ahead
fields.body:
Pfizer has hit back at AstraZeneca's claims that a takeover by the US company would risk lives by delaying the development of important drugs.

Ian Read, Pfizer's chief executive, said warnings that the proposed merger would disrupt AstraZeneca's promising drug pipeline were not valid.

After giving evidence to MPs on the business select committee on Tuesday, Read told the Independent: "In this integration, I frankly see no risk of delays for any important products for Pfizer or AstraZeneca. I'm afraid I think that's a real red herring."

He continued: "We would do the integration in a way that the scientists of both AstraZeneca and Pfizer would say 'these are projects that need to be kept on time, need to be ringfenced, need resources', and I have no doubt we would not slow up any of this development."

AstraZeneca's chief executive, Pascal Soriot, raised the stakes in the battle to fend off Pfizer by telling MPs a merged company would be distracted from potentially life-saving research by post-takeover financial manoeuvres.

He said: "What will we tell the person whose father died from lung cancer because one of our medicines was delayed – and essentially was delayed because in the meantime our two companies were involved in saving tax and saving costs?'

Read and Soriot are giving further evidence to parliament on Wednesday, this time to the science and technology committee.

Pfizer's proposed that £63bn takeover of AstraZeneca has become politically fraught amid fears that the US firm would cut science and manufacturing jobs in the UK. Such actions would undermine the government's attempts to make Britain a centre for scientific research and manufacturing.

Read stuck by his pledge to keep 20% of the combined company's research scientists in Britain but admitted there would be cuts in jobs and the combined research budget if the merger happened.

AstraZeneca announced on Wednesday that its MedImmune biologics arm would work with Incyte of the US on treatments that use the body's immune system to fight cancer.

Bahija Jallal, MedImmune's executive vice-president, said: "Immuno-oncology is one of the most exciting areas in our industry and we are progressing our strong pipeline as rapidly as possible. Our partnership with Incyte is further evidence of our belief that combination therapies have the potential to be one of the most effective ways of treating cancer."

webTitle: Britain's unemployment predicted to drop to half decade low

fields.standfirst: Figures expected to show level of joblessness has fallen to lowest rate since early 2009
fields.body:
Britain's unemployment rate is poised to hit a fresh five-year low with official figures on Wednesday morning widely expected to show the jobless rate continued to fall in the three months to March – while the pace of pay rises accelerated.

According to economists' forecasts Office for National Statistics data at 9.30am will show the unemployment rate was 6.8% in the three months to March, according to the consensus in a Reuters poll. That compares with 6.9% in December to February and would be the lowest rate since the start of 2009.

The forecast reflects upbeat recent business surveys with companies reporting they were hiring more staff to keep up with rising demand. But economists caution the rising number of people in work also reflects a sharp rise in self-employment, partly because frustrated jobseekers have been forced into working for themselves.

"We have pencilled in a 100,000 rise in employment in the three months to March. This could push the headline unemployment rate down to 6.8%. Note, though, that the rise in total employment has been largely driven by an increase in self-employment, which we have argued previously may mean that there is more slack in the labour market than the unemployment rate would suggest," the thinktank Capital Economics said in a preview note.

The consensus forecast is for wage growth to pick up to 2.1% for the three months to March on a year earlier compared with 1.7% growth in the last set of figures. The acceleration would put pay growth well ahead of inflation of 1.6% in March, marking an end to years of falling wages in real terms.

"Further strides are expected in the UK's jobs recovery," said Victoria Clarke, economist at Investec.

"The improvement in labour market conditions, including the pick-up in hiring reported in broader survey data, looks set to provide further support to real wage growth," Clarke adds, though she forecasts a slower rate of pay growth than the consensus, going for 1.8%.

The pick-up in economic growth and signs that wage growth is starting to gain momentum have fanned expectations the Bank of England could raise interest rates as soon as the end of this year, much earlier than next spring as policymakers have previously indicated. Rates have been at a record low of 0.5% for more than five years.

An hour after the labour market data, the Bank's governor Mark Carney presents policymakers' latest outlook for the economy in the quarterly Inflation Report.

Allan Monks, economist at JPMorgan expects a "modest change of tone" from February's report and that the forecasts will vindicate current market expectations for rate tightening to begin during the first quarter of 2015.

"This would be a slightly more hawkish message than sent in February. But it would still amount to a relatively small shift: a benign inflation backdrop is affording the monetary policy committee the space to signal that rates will remain on hold for a while longer, despite solid growth. At the same time, however, the BoE will be mindful that it may need to raise rates later this year: the unemployment rate is falling quickly, and there are early signs that pay growth could start picking up more rapidly," he said.

webTitle: Budget: roll out the bandages, we'll be bleeding for a while

fields.standfirst: A breakdown of the A to Z in portfolio cuts and spending ...
fields.body:
So what has been cut and what has been spent. Here’s a breakdown of some items by portfolio.

Agriculture

The big cut is ending the program to help improve supply chains in the live animal export industry. Animal welfare is no longer that important, saving $2.3m. However, there is $100m over four years extra funding for research and development in farming, and an extra $320m for drought assistance.

Attorney general’s

This includes the arts sector and there are big cuts there: $87m will be cut from arts funding provided by Screen Australia and the Australia Council and from the arts section of the department.

The government didn’t follow the lead of the Queensland premier, Campbell Newman, and cut the major literary awards; instead it cut the Get Reading! program.

It has also decided human rights aren’t a real priority, so it’s stopped the “human rights education program”. It will also reduce the number of human rights commissioners by one. Together that saves $3.5m over four years.

And the federal police? On your bike, son. There will be about 347 fewer AFP around; this will save $40m over four years. But there is $9.9m in new funding for the “national anti gang squad”.

Communications

Either Malcolm Turnbull doesn’t hold much sway in the cabinet room, or the communications minister really doesn’t like public broadcasting. The ABC and SBS are hit with a total of $43.5m in cuts through “efficiency”.

The portfolio does get some money though, mostly for mobile black spots: $100m over four years.

Defence

And here’s where the massive cuts come ... (that’s a joke for you latecomers). No cuts, just more spending: $25m to search for Malaysia Airlines flight MH370; $191m over four years to entice kids to join the armed forces during their “gap year” and $116m for operations in the Middle East to “contribute to international stabilisation and counterterrorism efforts”.

But the big expense is changing the veterans’ pension indexation to the higher average weekly earnings or CPI, in effect doing the exact opposite that it is doing to other pensions and welfare. That will cost $1.4bn over four years. And that is the main reason why the portfolio gets a total of $1.5bn extra funding over the next four years.

Education

You were really expecting more money here? Conservative governments hate public education funding, and this one is no exception. The education portfolio will see a drop in funding of $3.79bn over the next four years.

And in a further up-yours to those on the left, it has provided an extra $243m over four years for the chaplaincy program.

Employment

The priorities of this government in a nutshell: $1.2bn is “saved” by changes to Newstart for people under 30, and $304m is spent on a program to encourage employers to hire people over 50. The incentive for mature-age workers is quite sensible, but just imagine someone under 25 and someone of 50 ringing up Alan Jones or Ray Hadley to complain about not being about to get work. Who do you think would get the sympathy, and who do you think would get the abuse?

Environment

This government is not really big on the “environment”. It likes “conservation”, so the National Landcare program gets $1bn over four years, but it will cut funding to the program in net terms by $483.8m over five years by reducing grants. But no worries, because the government is also spending $50m over four years to plant 20m trees. So that’s climate changed solved.

Actually, on that issue, the big spend of course is the Direct Action plan. This will cost $2.55bn to establish the emissions reduction fund. But given $10m is cut from the Bureau of Meteorology, hopefully it can stop coming up with damn data that suggests climate change exists.

Finance

Fairly dull, mostly public service stuff. But it will cost $100m for scoping studies to sell Medibank Private, Australian Hearing, Defence Housing Australia Ltd, the Mint and the registry function of the Australian Securities and Investments Commission. Presumably at some point it might also explain why selling them would be a good idea.

Foreign affairs

Gee it’s good poor foreign people don’t vote. Foreign aid is cut by $7.6bn. The other big save is cutting the Australia Network contract with the ABC to save $196.8m. But we’re relocating our embassy in Baghdad to the UK embassy to save money and improve efficiencies and so on. Doing so will cost $35.6m.

Health

Big cuts all over the place: co-payments for GP visits, pausing the indexation of the threshold for the private health rebate and Medicare benefits schedule. Things that three years ago would have been class warfare. Now? Pfft.

But is this to pay off the deficit and debt? Nope. All these new and increased charges are savings which “will be invested by the government in the medical research future fund”. That fund which supposedly will grow to $20bn in a time far, far away. That fund will receive $276.2m over four years. But don’t worry. The government assures us that by 2022-23, $1bn a year will be invested. It’ll be interesting to see what we pay for each GP visit by then.

Hopefully the research fund finds a cure for lung cancer because we might be smoking more: $2.9m was cut from the national tobacco campaign.

Immigration

While there are big savings from fewer asylum seekers, the funding for Major-General Jim Molan as “the special envoy of Operation Sovereign Borders” remains at $1m over the next two years.

Industry

The government loves research, right? Well, only certain kinds of research, it seems. Funding for the CSIRO is cut by $111.4m, the Australian Nuclear Science and Technology Organisation by $27.6m and the Australian Institute of Marine Science by $7.8m.

And apprentices. Doesn’t this government love them as well? Sorry, guys, nearly $1bn is cut by ending the “tools for trade” program. Instead we have the establishment of the industry skills fund that gets $476m over four years.

Infrastructure

Lots of big “announceables” in this department. Pity most of them have already been announced. For example, the $1bn for the establishment of the national stronger regionals fund was announced on 29 August, 2013. The other big ticket items are the West Connex and Badgerys Creek roads funding.

As is often the case with these things, the funding looks really good if you draw it out over a long period. So the budget papers note funding for the western Sydney infrastructure plan is $2.9bn ... over 10 years. For now, it’s $1.2bn over four years, so not too shabby if you like roads and hate railways.

Prime minister and cabinet

Good thing the prime minister took the Indigenous affairs under his wing. Pity about the $534.4m in cuts to more than 150 programs, all in the name of “rationalisation”.

Social services

Big cuts to family payments, but any good news? Well, there’s $10m over three years to the Lebanese Muslim Association to build a residential aged care service that will “provide culturally appropriate aged care in western Sydney”. Which is actually a pretty nice thing to fund.

Treasury

Not a good time to be a tax officer; $143m in cuts to the ATO will see staffing fall by 4,700, although actually these were already on the axe due to decision by the former ALP government. The changes are just to bring them forward.

Veterans affairs

There a few savings in some programs by shifting payment dates around. But one of the new programs is $6.9m in 2014-15 to develop a detailed business case for the construction of an Australian western front interpretive centre at Villers‑Bretonneux in France. If it costs $6.9m just to make a business case for it, I can only wonder how much the actual centre will cost.

webTitle: China accuses British GlaxoSmithKline executive in bribery case

fields.standfirst: Announcements marks first time allegations have been levelled at a British employee of the drugs maker's China unit
fields.body:
Chinese police have accused a British executive in drugs maker GlaxoSmithKline's China unit of ordering his salespeople to bribe doctors and hospital officials to use the company's products.

Wednesday's announcement marks the first time a foreign employee in China of British-based GSK has been accused in connection with the bribery allegations against the company.

In a statement carried by the official Xinhua news agency, police in the central city of Changsha said Mark Reilly was accused of pressing his sales team to bribe doctors, hospital officials and health institutions. It said that resulted in "illegal revenue" of billions of yuan.

The statement said Reilly and two Chinese executives also were accused of bribing government officials in Beijing and Shanghai.

In April the GSK whistleblower Jarek Wisniewiski told the BBC's Panorama programme that company representatives paid doctors to boost prescriptions in Poland.

Another former GSK drug representative, who did not want to be identified, said they paid doctors for lectures that never happened and this would result in a greater number of prescriptions.

Wisniewiski said he had voiced his concerns with the drugs company but this resulted in him being sidelined at work and eventually sacked.

The programme said a criminal investigation was under way and 11 doctors and one GSK regional manager had been charged in connection with corruption.

If the new allegations were well founded GSK may have violated both the UK's Bribery Act and the US Foreign Corrupt Practices Act, the BBC programme said. It is illegal for companies based in the US or UK to bribe government employees abroad.
